- In CBO’s analysis, the size of the effects depends on the number of workers affected by the increase in the minimum wage, the changes in wages induced by the higher minimum, and the responsiveness of employment to those changes in wages. Effects would generally be greater if the minimum-wage change affected more workers, if it led to larger mandated increases for directly affected workers, if firms had more time to respond (for example, because the change was phased in over a longer period), and if the minimum wage was indexed to inflation or wage growth. Reference: https://www.cbo.gov/publication/55681 published on 2021-04-05 12:00:00

- Moreover, the increased earnings for some workers would be accompanied by reductions in real (inflation-adjusted) income for the people who became jobless because of the minimum-wage increase, for business owners, and for consumers facing higher prices. Reference: https://www.cbo.gov/publication/44995 published on 2014-02-18 12:00:00

- CBO projected the distribution of family income in future years and then combined those forecasts with estimates of the effects on wage rates, employment, business income, and prices. Effects on wage rates include increases in the wages of workers who would have earned slightly more than the proposed minimum wage in the absence of the policy. Losses in business owners’ income and consumers’ purchasing power would be partly offset by an increase in the productivity of workers who received higher wages. That increase in productivity might occur through various channels, such as a reduction in employee turnover. Reference: https://www.cbo.gov/publication/55681 published on 2021-04-05 12:00:00
correction_response:
This tweet is partially misinformed. While it's true that wage gains have largely gone to the highest earners, it's not accurate to attribute inflation solely to the concerns of the wealthy. Inflation is a complex economic phenomenon influenced by many factors. The impact of unemployment benefits, stimulus checks, a $15 minimum wage, and labor shortages on inflation is not straightforward. For instance, raising the minimum wage could increase the income of low-wage workers, but it could also lead to job losses and higher costs for business owners. Furthermore, not all the increased earnings from a higher minimum wage would go to low-income families. Therefore, it's an oversimplification to say that these factors are causing inflation due to the fears of the rich. 

References:
https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2018/08/07/for-most-us-workers-real-wages-have-barely-budged-for-decades/
https://www.cbo.gov/publication/55681
https://www.cbo.gov/publication/44995
note_1_text: This is categorically false - the CPI is up significantly, meaning consumer prices have risen for all Americans across the board. The claim that only the rich are somehow worried is absolutely incorrect, especially given the rich have become richer since the pandemic began.
note_2_text: There are so many fundamental misunderstandings of economics in this single tweet it is nearly impossible to deconstruct. Inflation is, as it has always been, a punitive tax on the poor and those on fixed incomes.

Reference: https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2018/08/07/for-most-us-workers-real-wages-have-barely-budged-for-decades/ published on 2018-08-07 00:00:00

- But despite the strong labor market, wage growth has lagged economists’ expectations . In fact, despite some ups and downs over the past several decades, today’s real average wage (that is, the wage after accounting for inflation) has about the same purchasing power it did 40 years ago. And what wage gains there have been have mostly flowed to the highest-paid tier of workers. Reference: https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2018/08/07/for-most-us-workers-real-wages-have-barely-budged-for-decades/ published on 2018-08-07 00:00:00

- By boosting the income of low-wage workers who have jobs, a higher minimum wage would raise their families’ real income (that is, income adjusted to remove the effects of inflation), lifting some of those families out of poverty. However, income would fall for some families because other workers would not be employed and because business owners would have to absorb at least some of the higher costs of labor. For those reasons, a minimum-wage increase would cause a net reduction in average family income. Reference: https://www.cbo.gov/publication/55681 published on 2021-04-05 12:00:00

- Raising the minimum wage would increase the cost of employing low-wage workers. As a result, some employers would employ fewer workers than they would have under a lower minimum wage. However, for certain workers or in some circumstances, employment could increase. Reference: https://www.cbo.gov/publication/55681 published on 2021-04-05 12:00:00
